abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome was
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, and institutional
            development impacts only modest. Lessons learned are as
            follows. Since the risk that Congress would not enact all of
            the envisaged legislation was not only recognized, but was
            actually a main subject of discussion during negotiations,
            the explicit mention (on the President Report) of such risks
            should have specified the enactment of contentious
            legislation into the conditionality of the operation.
            Moreover, given that monitoring, and enforcement of
            implementation is particularly difficult in a complex,
            multi-tranche adjustment operation, specifically in light of
            uncertain supportive legislative reforms, the effectiveness
            of some regulatory changes related to large banks remains
            questionable, possibly the credibility itself of such
            changes. Thus it is fair to say, that cutting losses, and
            canceling should be readily employed, much preferable if
            solutions are unlikely to achieve the development objective,
            a conclusion which should have been reached much earlier.
            While restructuring is also an option to consider,
            preferable to allowing difficult issues to continue, it is
            suggested that single-tranche operations may be preferable
            to multi-tranche operations, to avoid actions beyond the
            control of the executive.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Banking System Reform Project seeks
            to support the country's banking reform program to
            strengthen the banking system and enable it to better
            withstand current difficulties and future shocks. The focus
            of this program is to: a) improve on an ongoing basis the
            incentives for supervisors, bank owners, and the market to
            strengthen the framework for prudent banking; b) enhance the
            framework and the authorities' preparedness for early
            intervention and resolution of troubled banks; c) strengthen
            Philippine National Bank towards the standards maintained by
            the top tier banks in the country; and d) reduce the
            incentives for regulatory and tax arbitrage across financial
            institutions, and between the peso and foreign currencies.
            The loan provides balance of payments support to the
            Philippines when the country's access to private
            capital has been sharply reduced. It will also build
            international reserves, reduce the pressure on domestic
            resources to finance the budget deficit, and enhance market
            confidence in the banking program. A loan of US$ 300 million
            will be disbursed in three equal tranches. However, the risk
            is that the economy remains vulnerable to a deterioration in
            the regional environment. Also the banking system faces
            continuing risks from economic slowdown, tighter credit,
            peso depreciation, and weaker real estate prices. By
            engaging the authorities in an ongoing dialogue, the Bank
            can strengthen the program and enhance the investor
            confidence in the program.
